intro: Oenothera micrantha var. ignota, commonly known as the desert evening primrose, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its showy yellow to orange flowers that open in the evening, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as moths. The plant has slender, branching stems and narrow, lance-shaped leaves that are adapted to arid environments. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in desert scrub and rocky habitats. The species is noted for its ability to withstand drought conditions and its role in supporting local pollinator populations.
